posts.description: Perform tasks or take actions within the Shopify admin.
posts.title: Actions
posts.shortDescription: Perform tasks or take actions within the Shopify admin.

children.description: The account connection component is used so merchants can connect or disconnect their store to various accounts. For example, if merchants want to use the Facebook sales channel, they need to connect their Facebook account to their Shopify store.
children.title: Account connection
children.shortDescription: Used for connecting or disconnecting a store to various accounts, like Facebook for the sales channel.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to let merchants connect or disconnect their store to their third-party accounts, like Facebook.

children.description: Buttons are used primarily for actions, such as “Add”, “Close”, “Cancel”, or “Save”. Plain buttons, which look similar to links, are used for less important or less commonly used actions, such as “view shipping settings”.
children.title: Button
children.shortDescription: Used primarily for actions like 'Add', 'Close', 'Cancel', or 'Save'. Plain buttons are used for less important actions.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Used most in the interface. Only use another style if a button requires more or less visual weight.

examples.title: Plain
examples.description: Use for less important or less commonly used actions since they’re less prominent. For example, plain buttons are used as actions in cards.

examples.title: Tertiary
examples.description: Use for tertiary actions. Can be paired with any other button style to create visual variation.

examples.title: Plain critical
examples.description: Use for actions that will delete merchant data or be otherwise difficult to recover from. Since they’re less prominent, use for less important or less commonly used critical actions. For example, plain buttons are used as actions in cards.

examples.title: Primary
examples.description: Use to highlight the most important actions in any experience. Don’t use more than one primary button in a section or screen to avoid overwhelming merchants.

examples.title: Primary critical
examples.description: Use when the action will delete merchant data or be otherwise difficult to recover from. Critical buttons should trigger a confirmation dialog before the action is completed. Be thoughtful about using critical buttons because they can feel stressful for merchants.

examples.title: Large
examples.description: Use for the main call to action in empty states or for calls to action shown with large illustrations.

examples.title: Full-width
examples.description: Use for buttons placed in a narrow column (especially when stacking multiple buttons) or for creating a set of buttons of equal width. Full-width buttons should rarely exceed 320 px wide.

examples.title: Text-aligned
examples.description: Use for plain or monochrome buttons that could have a long length and should be aligned when they potentially overflow onto the next line.

examples.title: Pressed
examples.description: Buttons are sometimes used as a toggle for other parts of the user interface.

examples.title: Plain disclosure
examples.description: Use to indicate that more content can be disclosed on click, like text in a collapsible.

examples.title: Right-aligned disclosure
examples.description: When working with `fullWidth + textAlign="left"`, the `disclosure` will align itself to the far right.

examples.title: Select disclosure
examples.description: Use to indicate that multiple options are available from this control, similar to a `<select />` HTML element.

examples.title: Split
examples.description: Use when there is only one primary action but other related actions can be taken.

examples.title: Disabled state
examples.description: Use for actions that aren’t currently available. The surrounding interface should make it clear why the button is disabled and what needs to be done to enable it.

examples.title: Loading state
examples.description: Use when a button has been pressed and the associated action is in progress.

children.description: Button group displays multiple related actions stacked or in a horizontal row to help with arrangement and spacing.
children.title: Button group
children.shortDescription: Displays multiple related actions stacked or in a horizontal row for arrangement and spacing.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when you have multiple buttons to space them out evenly.

examples.title: With segmented buttons
examples.description: Use to emphasize several buttons as a thematically-related set among other controls.

examples.title: Pressed with segmented buttons
examples.description: Pressed buttons can be used in combination to create a toggle for other parts of the user interface.

children.description: Page actions let merchants take key actions at the bottom of specific pages in the interface. This is important because sometimes the primary call to action is hard to access when merchants are at the bottom of a page.
children.title: Page actions
children.shortDescription: Allows merchants to take key actions at the bottom of specific pages in the interface.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Used on a resource page (such as an individual order or product page) to let merchants take key actions at the bottom of the page. Usually, the primary action is Save and the secondary action is Delete.

examples.title: Primary action only
examples.description: Not all page actions require a secondary action.

examples.title: With custom primary action
examples.description: Use to create a custom primary action.

examples.title: With custom secondary action
examples.description: Use to create a custom secondary action.

posts.description: Layout is the arrangement of elements on a page. A good layout helps merchants understand and find information to complete their goals. To learn more, visit the Layout documentation.
posts.title: Layout and structure
posts.shortDescription: The arrangement of elements on a page that helps merchants understand and find information to complete their goals.

children.description: Applies negative margin to allow content to bleed out into the surrounding layout.
children.title: Bleed
children.shortDescription: Applies negative margin to a layout, extending it to the edge of the screen on small screens.

examples.title: Horizontal
examples.description: Content will bleed horizontally into the surrounding layout using the `marginInline` prop.

examples.title: Vertical
examples.description: Content will bleed vertically into the surrounding layout using the `marginBlock` prop.

examples.title: Specific direction
examples.description: Negative margins can be added in a specific direction using the [Space tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/space).

children.description: Use to display children vertically and horizontally with full width by default. Based on CSS Flexbox.
children.title: Block stack

examples.title: Gap
examples.description: Control the vertical space between children using the `gap` prop.

examples.title: Align
examples.description: Control the vertical alignment of children using the `align` prop.

examples.title: Inline align
examples.description: Control the horizontal alignment of children using the `inlineAlign` prop.

children.description: Box is the most primitive layout component. It’s a way to access Polaris design tokens.
children.title: Box

examples.title: Color
examples.description: Background color of box and text color inside a box can be adjusted using the [Color tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/color).

examples.title: Border width
examples.description: Border width can be adjusted using the [Border tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/border), and a subset of tokens allows different types of border.

examples.title: Border radius
examples.description: Border radius can be adjusted using the [Border tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/border).

examples.title: Padding
examples.description: Padding can be added to either all sides, left, right, top, and bottom, using the [Space tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/space). The `padding` prop supports responsive spacing with the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

examples.title: Shadow
examples.description: Shadow can be applied using the [Shadow tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/shadow).

children.description: Callout cards are used to encourage merchants to take an action related to a new feature or opportunity. They are most commonly displayed in the sales channels section of Shopify.
children.title: Callout card

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to let merchants know about a feature or opportunity where there is a clear, single action they need to take to move to the next step.

examples.title: With secondary action
examples.description: Use to let merchants know about a feature or opportunity where there are two distinct actions they can take on the information.

examples.title: Dismissable
examples.description: Make all callout cards dismissible so merchants can get rid of cards about features they’re not interested in.

children.description: Cards are used to group similar concepts and tasks together for merchants to scan, read, and get things done. It displays content in a familiar and recognizable style.
children.title: Card
children.shortDescription: Used to group similar concepts and tasks together for easier scanning and reading.
keywords: card with call to action in the footer
card with call to action in the heading
card with call to action in a section
card with button in the footer
card with button in the heading

examples.title: Default
examples.description: By default, cards have an 8px border radius and uses `--p-color-bg-surface` as the background and `--p-shadow-300` as the shadow. There is padding of `space-5` (20px) around children and `space-4` (16px) for small screens.

examples.title: With subdued background
examples.description: Use for content that you want to deprioritize. Subdued cards don’t stand out as much as cards with white backgrounds so don’t use them for information or actions that are critical to merchants.

examples.title: With varying padding
examples.description: Use the `padding` property to adjust the spacing within a card. You can also specify spacing values at different breakpoints.

examples.title: Rounded corners
examples.description: Use the `padding` property to adjust the spacing of content within a card. The `padding` prop supports responsive spacing with the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

children.description: Use to separate or group content.
children.title: Divider

examples.title: Color
examples.description: Divider border color can be adjusted using the [Color tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/color).

children.description: Empty states are used when a list, table, or chart has no items or data to show. This is an opportunity to provide explanation or guidance to help merchants progress. The empty state component is intended for use when a full page in the admin is empty, and not for individual elements or areas in the interface.
children.title: Empty state

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to explain a single feature before merchants have used it.

examples.title: With subdued footer context
examples.description: Use to provide additional but non-critical context for a new product or feature. Can also be used to include a subdued call to action for secondary or tertiary actions.

children.description: Use form layout to arrange fields within a form using standard spacing. By default it stacks fields vertically but also supports horizontal groups of fields.
children.title: Form layout
children.shortDescription: Manages the layout of all forms and fields within it. Used for the layout of new forms and managing the layout of all forms.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to stack form fields vertically, which makes them easier to scan and complete.

examples.title: Field group
examples.description: Use field groups to arrange multiple fields in a row. Works best for familiar layouts such as a row of city, state, and zip code fields. Use caution when arranging unrelated fields next to each other as this makes fields easier to miss. Field groups will wrap automatically on smaller screens.

examples.title: Condensed field group
examples.description: For very short inputs, the width of the inputs may be reduced in order to fit more fields in the row.

children.description: Create complex layouts based on CSS Grid.
children.title: Grid

examples.title: Two column
examples.description: Use to create a two column layout that wraps at a breakpoint and aligns to a twelve column grid.

examples.title: Two-thirds and one-third column
examples.description: Use to create a two-thirds, one-third column layout that wraps at a breakpoint and aligns to a twelve column grid.

examples.title: Three one-third column
examples.description: Use to create a three column layout that wrap at a breakpoint and aligns to a twelve column grid.

examples.title: Custom layout
examples.description: Use to create a layout that can be customized at specific breakpoints.

children.description: Use to lay out children horizontally with equal gap between columns. Based on CSS Grid.
children.title: Inline grid

examples.title: Gap
examples.description: Use the `gap` prop to set the amount of space between columns. The `gap` prop supports responsive spacing with the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

examples.title: Column width
examples.description: The `columns` property accepts CSS column shorthand syntax, or an array of strings mapping to common widths in the admin such as `oneThird`, `oneHalf`, and `twoThirds`. For responsive columns, use the same syntax passed into an object with the breakpoints.

examples.title: Number of columns
examples.description: Control the number of columns using the `columns` prop. Column numbers can be responsively set using the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

children.description: Use to display children horizontally in a row. Based on CSS Flexbox.
children.title: Inline stack

examples.title: Non-wrapping
examples.description: The default wrapping behavior of children can be overridden using the `wrap` prop.

examples.title: Gap
examples.description: Control the horizontal and vertical space between children using the `gap` prop. The `gap` prop supports responsive spacing with the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

examples.title: Block align
examples.description: Control the vertical alignment of children using the `blockAlign` prop.

examples.title: Align
examples.description: Control the horizontal alignment of children using the `align` prop.

children.description: The layout component is used to create the main layout on a page. Layouts sections come in three main configurations. one-column, two-column, and annotated. One and two column layouts can be combined in the same page. Annotated layouts should be used on their own and only on settings pages.
children.title: Layout
children.shortDescription: A structural component used to group other components. Creates consistent spacing and helps layout stack and scale responsively.

examples.title: One-column
examples.description: Use to have a single section on its own in a full-width container. Use for simple pages and as a container for banners and other full-width content.

examples.title: Two columns with primary and secondary widths
examples.description: Use to follow a normal section with a secondary section to create a 2/3 + 1/3 layout on detail pages (such as individual product or order pages). Can also be used on any page that needs to structure a lot of content. This layout stacks the columns on small screens.

examples.title: Two columns with equal width
examples.description: Use to create a ½ + ½ layout. Can be used to display content of equal importance. This layout will stack the columns on small screens.

examples.title: Three columns with equal width
examples.description: Use to create a ⅓ + ⅓ + ⅓ layout. Can be used to display content of equal importance. This layout will stack the columns on small screens.

examples.title: Annotated
examples.description: Use for settings pages. When settings are grouped thematically in annotated sections, the title and description on each section helps merchants quickly find the setting they’re looking for.

examples.title: Annotated with sections
examples.description: Use for settings pages. When settings are grouped thematically in annotated sections, the title and description on each section helps merchants quickly find the setting they’re looking for.

examples.title: Annotated with Banner at the top
examples.description: Use for settings pages that need a banner or other content at the top.

children.description: Media cards provide a consistent layout to present visual information to merchants. Visual media is used to provide additional context to the written information it's paired with.
children.title: Media card
children.shortDescription: Provides a container for introductory or highlight information. Often used in a grid to present related content.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to surface educational information about a feature or opportunity.

examples.title: With small visual
examples.description: Use when there are limited vertical space, or when the card should be less prominent.

examples.title: With secondary action
examples.description: Use when there are two distinct actions merchants can take on the information in the card.

examples.title: With no actions
examples.description: Use when media card does not require any actions.

examples.title: Video card
examples.description: Use to provide a consistent layout for contextual learning content. Use to wrap thumbnails of educational videos about Shopify features in context.

examples.title: Portrait video card
examples.description: Use when vertical screen space is not limited or when the video card is the page’s primary content. For example, in an empty state.

children.description: Use to build the outer wrapper of a page, including the page title and associated actions.
children.title: Page
children.shortDescription: Used to build the layout of a page in the Shopify admin. A flexible container for composing pages consistently.
keywords: page without primary action in header

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use for detail pages, which should have pagination and breadcrumbs, and also often have several actions.

examples.title: With custom primary action
examples.description: Use to create a custom primary action.

examples.title: Without primary action in header
examples.description: Use when a primary action functions better as part of the page content instead of in the page header.

examples.title: With destructive secondary action
examples.description: Used to visually indicate that the secondary page action is destructive.

examples.title: With custom secondary action
examples.description: Use to create a custom secondary action.

examples.title: With tooltip action
examples.description: Use when merchants or their staff will benefit from context on why a page action is disabled.

examples.title: With subtitle
examples.description: Use when the page title benefits from secondary content.

examples.title: With external link
examples.description: Use when a secondary action links to another website. Actions marked external open in a new browser tab.

examples.title: Without pagination
examples.description: Use when the page doesn’t represent a list of objects or a detail view for an object.

examples.title: Full-width
examples.description: Use for layouts that benefit from more screen width, such as wide tables or lists.

examples.title: Narrow width
examples.description: Use a narrow width layout if the page supports a single unified task. When merchants must review the entire page contents to complete their goal, this layout helps focus their attention in a single path from top to bottom.

examples.title: With action groups
examples.description: Use action groups for sets of actions that relate to one another, particularly when there are too many to display as secondary actions. Note that these groups will be further rolled up into a single action for smaller displays so that actions do not wrap or overflow the page bounds.

examples.title: With content after title
examples.description: Title metadata appears immediately after the page’s title. Use it to communicate brief, important and non-interactive status information about an entire page.

posts.description: Choose or enter information using elements like checkboxes, text fields, and more.
posts.title: Selection and input

children.description: The autocomplete component is an input field that provides selectable suggestions as a merchant types into it. It allows merchants to quickly search through and select from large collections of options. It's a convenience wrapper around the Combobox and Listbox components with minor UI differences.
children.title: Autocomplete

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to help merchants complete text input quickly from a list of options.

examples.title: With multiple tags
examples.description: Use to help merchants select multiple options from a list curated by the text input.

examples.title: With multiple sections
examples.description: Use to help merchants complete text input quickly from a multiple sections list of options.

examples.title: With loading
examples.description: Use to indicate loading state to merchants while option data is processing.

examples.title: With empty state
examples.description: Use to indicate there are no search results.

examples.title: With action
examples.description: Use to help merchants complete an action quickly.

examples.title: With wrapping action
examples.description: Use to help merchants complete an action quickly with wrapping lines of text.

examples.title: With destructive action
examples.description: Use to help merchants complete a destructive action quickly.

children.description: Checkboxes are most commonly used to give merchants a way to make a range of selections (zero, one, or multiple). They may also be used as a way to have merchants indicate they agree to specific terms and services.
children.title: Checkbox

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use in forms to toggle the state of something on or off. Default checkboxes can appear as selected and disabled, or unselected.

children.description: A choice list lets you create a list of grouped radio buttons or checkboxes. Use this component if you need to group together a related list of interactive choices.
children.title: Choice list

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Allows merchants to select one option from a list. Make sure all options are an either/or choice.

examples.title: With error
examples.description: Allows for accessible error handling by connecting the error message to the field with the error.

examples.title: With multi-choice
examples.description: Allows merchants to select multiple options from a list. Avoid options that are an either/or choice.

examples.title: With children content
examples.description: Use when you need merchants to view and/or interact with additional content under a choice. The content will always be rendered.

examples.title: With dynamic children content
examples.description: Use when you need merchants to view and/or interact with additional content under a choice. The content is only rendered when the choice is selected. Works for both single-choice and multi-choice list.

children.description: The color picker is used to let merchants select a color visually. For example, merchants use the color picker to customize the accent color of the email templates for their shop.
children.title: Color picker
children.shortDescription: Allows merchants to choose a color visually, or by entering a hex value.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when merchants need to select a color to make the selection a visual task rather than a technical one.

examples.title: With transparent value
examples.description: Use when attached to a visual builder to allow the designated object to have a transparent background that allows underlying objects to show through.

examples.title: With transparent value full width
examples.description: Use when attached to a visual builder to allow the designated object to have a transparent background that allows underlying objects to show through.

children.description: Combobox is an accessible autocomplete input that enables merchants to filter a list of options and select one or more values.
children.title: Combobox

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when merchants can select one option from a predefined or editable list.

examples.title: With manual selection
examples.description: Use when merchants can select one option from a predefined or editable list.

examples.title: With multi-select
examples.description: Use when merchants can select one or more options from a predefined or editable list.

examples.title: With multi-select and manual selection
examples.description: Use when merchants can select one or more options from a predefined or editable list.

examples.title: With multi-select and vertical content
examples.description: Use to display selected options above the input value.

examples.title: With loading
examples.description: Use to indicate to merchants that the list data is being fetched.

children.description: The contextual save bar tells merchants their options once they have made changes to a form on the page. This component is also shown while creating a new object like a product or customer. Merchants can use this component to save or discard their work.
children.title: Contextual save bar
children.shortDescription: Informs merchants of their options once they have made changes to a form on the page or while creating a new object.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use the save action to provide an opportunity to save changes. Use the discard action to allow merchants the option to discard their changes. Use the message to provide helpful context on the nature of those changes.

examples.title: With flush contents
examples.description: Use the alignContentFlush flag when you want to omit the logo from the contextual save bar and repurpose that space to extend the message contents fully to the left side of the container.

examples.title: With full width
examples.description: Use the fullWidth flag when you want to remove the default max-width set on the contextual save bar.

children.description: Date pickers let merchants choose dates from a visual calendar that’s consistently applied wherever dates need to be selected across Shopify.
children.title: Date picker

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when merchants need to select a single day close to today (today is the default starting position for the date picker).

examples.title: Ranged
examples.description: Use when merchants need to select a range of days close to today (today is the default starting position for the date picker).

examples.title: Multi-month ranged
examples.description: Use multi-month mode to show two months at a time.

examples.title: With disabled date ranges
examples.description: Date ranges may be disabed if you do not want them to be selectable

examples.title: With specific disabled dates
examples.description: Dates may be disabed if you do not want them to be selectable

children.description: The drop zone component lets users upload files by dragging and dropping the files into an area on a page, or activating a button.
children.title: Drop zone

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to upload files. They can drag and drop files into the dashed area, or upload traditionally by clicking the “Add file” button or anywhere inside the dashed area.

examples.title: With a label
examples.description: Use to pair with a label for better accessibility.

examples.title: With image file upload
examples.description: Use for cases that accept image file formats.

examples.title: With single file upload
examples.description: Use to accept only one file.

examples.title: With drop on page
examples.description: Use to accept files for upload when dropped anywhere on the page.

examples.title: Accepts only SVG files
examples.description: Use to accept only SVG files.

examples.title: Nested
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to upload files in a wider area than the visible drop zone.

examples.title: Medium-sized
examples.description: Use for cases with limited space. To improve usability, nest medium-sized drop zone in a larger drop zone with no outline. See the nested dropzone example.

examples.title: Small-sized
examples.description: Use for cases with tight space constraints, such as variant thumbnails on the Product details page. To improve usability, nest small-sized drop zone in a larger drop zone with no outline. See the nested dropzone example.

examples.title: With custom FileUpload text
examples.description: Use for cases where you want the child contents of the dropzone to determine its height.

examples.title: With custom file dialog trigger
examples.description: Use to trigger the file dialog from an action somewhere else on the page.

children.description: Filters is a composite component that filters the items of a list or table.
children.title: Filters
children.shortDescription: A composite component that filters the items of a list or table.

children.description: A wrapper component that handles the submission of forms.
children.title: Form

examples.title: Custom onSubmit
examples.description: Use onSubmit as a callback for when your form is submitted.

examples.title: Without native validation
examples.description: Use in forms to toggle native form validation.

children.description: Use index filters to allow merchants to filter, search, and sort their index table data and create unique saved views from the results.
children.title: Index filters

examples.title: Default
examples.description: An IndexFilters component with view management, search, filtering, and sorting.

examples.title: With pinned filters
examples.description: An IndexFilters component with some of the filters pinned, making them visible by default.

examples.title: Filtering mode default
examples.description: An IndexFilters component with filtering mode enabled by default.

examples.title: Disabled
examples.description: An IndexFilters component that is disabled.

examples.title: With no filters
examples.description: An IndexFilters component with only view management, search, and sorting.

examples.title: With no search or filters
examples.description: An IndexFilters component with only view management and sorting.

children.description: Inline errors are brief, in-context messages that tell merchants something went wrong with a single or group of inputs in a form. Use inline errors to help merchants understand why a form input may not be valid and how to fix it.
children.title: Inline error

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when the merchant has entered information that is not valid into multiple fields inside of a form, or needs to be displayed in a non-standard position in the form layout.

children.description: Use radio buttons to present each item in a list of options where merchants must make a single selection.
children.title: Radio button

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use radio buttons where merchants must make a single selection.

children.description: A range slider is an input field that merchants can use to select a numeric value within a given range (minimum and maximum values).
children.title: Range slider

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when a single value between `0 and 100` needs to be selected.

examples.title: With min and max
examples.description: Use when a single value needs to be selected from a number range with a specific minimum and maximum.

examples.title: With steps
examples.description: Use when a single value of a specific increment needs to be selected from a range of numbers.

examples.title: With prefix and suffix
examples.description: Use when the start or end of the range input benefits from additional content. The height of the range slider component varies based on the presence or absence of props like `label` and `helpText`. Setting a React element on the `prefix` and `suffix` props is supported to enable control of spacing and alignment.

examples.title: With dual thumb
examples.description: Use when two values need to be selected from a range of numbers.

children.description: Select lets merchants choose one option from an options menu. Consider select when you have 4 or more options, to avoid cluttering the interface.
children.title: Select

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Presents a classic dropdown menu or equivalent picker as determined by merchants’ browsers.

examples.title: With inline label
examples.description: Use only for cases where the select must fit on a single line, such as in a toolbar.

examples.title: Disabled
examples.description: Use for selections that aren’t currently available. The surrounding interface should make it clear why the select box is disabled and how to activate it.

examples.title: With prefix
examples.description: Renders any React element to the left of individual select options. Does not show in the dropdown.

examples.title: With validation error
examples.description: Use to let merchants know if there’s a problem with their selection. For selects, a selection is typically invalid only when using a placeholder option (“Select”) and no other selection has been made.

examples.title: With separate validation error
examples.description: Use to let merchants know when their select input is invalid in the context of a group of form inputs that the select depends on.

children.description: Tags represent a set of interactive, merchant-supplied keywords that help label, organize, and categorize objects. Tags can be added or removed from an object by merchants.
children.title: Tag

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to signify the attributes of an object.

examples.title: Removable
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to remove attributes from an object.

examples.title: Clickable
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to add attributes to an object.

examples.title: With link
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to navigate to a resource. For example a customer segment or a smart collection

examples.title: With custom content
examples.description: Use when a tag needs to be visually distinguished from others, like when it's added automatically.

examples.title: Removable with link
examples.description: A removable attribute to an object that allows merchants to navigate to a resource.

children.description: A text field is an input field that merchants can type into. It has a range of options and supports several text formats including numbers.
children.title: Text field

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to provide text input when the expected input is short. For longer input, use the auto grow or multiline options.

examples.title: Number
examples.description: Use when input text should be a number.

examples.title: Email
examples.description: Use when the text input should be an email address.

examples.title: Multiline
examples.description: Use when the expected input could be more than one line. The field will automatically grow to accommodate additional text.

examples.title: With hidden label
examples.description: Use to visually hide the label when the text field’s purpose is clear from context. The label will remain available to screen readers. Use this option with care. In almost all cases, show the label.

examples.title: With label action
examples.description: Use when an optional, secondary action is closely associated with a text field. For example, on a field for entering a customs tariff code, a label action might be to look up the appropriate code from a table.

examples.title: With right aligned text
examples.description: Use when input text should be aligned right.

examples.title: With placeholder text
examples.description: Use to provide a short, non-essential hint about the expected input. Placeholder text is low-contrast, so don’t rely on it for important information.

examples.title: With help text
examples.description: Use to show short instructional content below the text field. Help text works to help merchants understand how to fix errors that result from incorrect formatting (such as dates or passwords with specific character requirements). If more explanation is needed, link to the Shopify Help Center.

examples.title: With prefix or suffix
examples.description: Use as a special form of help text that works best inline. Use a prefix for things like currency symbols (“\$”, “¥”, “£”). Use suffix for things like units of measure (“in”, “cm”).

examples.title: With vertical content
examples.description: Use to include custom vertical content above the input value, like selected tags.

examples.title: With connected fields
examples.description: Use when a text field and several related fields make up a logical unit. If inputting weight as a number and a separate unit of measurement, use a text field with a [select dropdown menu](https://polaris.shopify.com/components/select) (for example “kg”, “lb”) as a connected field.

examples.title: With validation error
examples.description: Use to let merchants know if their input is valid or if there’s an error. Whenever possible, validate input as soon as merchants have finished interacting with a field (but not before). If a field already has an error, validate and remove errors as merchants type so they can immediately see when an error has been fixed.

examples.title: With separate validation error
examples.description: Use to let merchants know when their text field input is invalid in the context of a group of form inputs that the text field depends on.

examples.title: Disabled
examples.description: Use to show that a textfield is not available for interaction. Most often used in forms when information is required only in a particular state. For example, the text field next to Other in a choice list when Other is not selected.

examples.title: With character count
examples.description: Use to display the current number of characters in a text field. Use in conjunction with max length to display the current remaining number of characters in the text field.

examples.title: With clear button
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to clear the content from a text field.

examples.title: With monospaced font
examples.description: Use to apply a monospaced font to the TextField

examples.title: With value selected on focus
examples.description: Use to select all text inside TextField on focus.

examples.title: With inline suggestion
examples.description: Use to provide an autocomplete suggestion inline with the input value. See the combobox component's tag multi-select example for full implementation of the inline autocomplete pattern.

posts.description: Represent visual content, such as avatars and thumbnails for images or video.
posts.title: Images and icons
posts.shortDescription: Represent visual content, such as avatars and thumbnails for images or video.

children.description: Avatars are used to show a thumbnail representation of an individual or business in the interface.
children.title: Avatar
children.shortDescription: Used to show a thumbnail representation of an individual or business in the interface.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to present an avatar for a merchant, customer, or business.

examples.title: Initials
examples.description: Use to present an avatar with initials for a merchant, customer, or business.

examples.title: Extra small
examples.description: Use to present an avatar in a condensed layout, such as a data table cell or an action list item.

children.description: Icons are used to visually communicate core parts of the product and available actions. They can act as wayfinding tools to help merchants more easily understand where they are in the product, and common interaction patterns that are available.
children.title: Icon
children.shortDescription: Used to visually communicate core parts of the product and available actions, acting as wayfinding tools.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to visually communicate core parts of the product and available actions.

examples.title: Colored
examples.description: Apply a color to the icon.

examples.title: With custom SVG
examples.description: Specify an SVG as a string to render it in an image tag, instead of an inline SVG to prevent script injection.

examples.title: With custom SVG and color
examples.description: When using changing color of an svg and it uses currentColor, the white color is applied.

children.description: Keyboard key is used to educate merchants about keyboard shortcuts.
children.title: Keyboard key
children.shortDescription: Used to educate merchants about keyboard shortcuts.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to list a related set of keyboard shortcuts.

children.description: Use thumbnails as a visual anchor and identifier for an object. They should be used along with text to provide context.
children.title: Thumbnail
children.shortDescription: Used as a visual anchor and identifier for an object, along with text to provide context.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use as the default size.

examples.title: Extra small
examples.description: Use to present a thumbnail in a condensed layout, such as a data table cell or an action list item.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use when the default size is too large for the layout, or when the thumbnail has less importance.

examples.title: Large
examples.description: Use when a thumbnail is a major focal point. Avoid this size in lists of like items.

examples.title: With component source
examples.description: Use to render an icon inside of thumbnail.

children.description: Video thumbnails are a clickable placeholder image. When clicked, it opens a video player within a modal or full screen.
children.title: Video thumbnail
children.shortDescription: A clickable placeholder image that opens a video player within a modal or full screen when clicked.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use as a play button for a video player within a media card.

examples.title: With progress
examples.description: Use to indicate the video’s play progress in relation to its duration.

posts.description: Inform merchants about the status of a process, provide feedback on actions and tasks, or indicate progress.
posts.title: Feedback indicators
posts.shortDescription: Inform merchants about the status of a process, provide feedback, or indicate progress.

children.description: Badges are used to inform merchants of the tone of an object or of an action that’s been taken.
children.title: Badge
children.shortDescription: Used to inform merchants of the tone of an object or an action taken.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to give a non-critical tone update on a piece of information or action.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use in layouts with minimal space, like inside of an `IndexTable` cell.

examples.title: Informational
examples.description: Use to call out an object or action as having an important attribute. For example, marking an option as “Recommended” or marking a theme as “Published”.

examples.title: Success
examples.description: Use to indicate a successful, completed, or desirable state when it’s important to provide positive reinforcement to merchants. For example, when merchants successfully dispute a chargeback, a success badge shows that says “Funds recovered”.

examples.title: Attention
examples.description: Use when something requires merchants’ attention but the issue isn’t critical. For example, this badge would show next to an order that needs to be reviewed by merchants.

examples.title: Warning
examples.description: Use for warnings and time-sensitive issues that require merchants’ attention and potential action. Warning events are often reversible. Keep in mind that seeing this badge can feel stressful for merchants so it should only be used when absolutely necessary.

examples.title: Critical
examples.description: Use for critical and irreversible issues that require merchants’ attention and potential action. Keep in mind that seeing this badge can feel stressful for merchants so it should only be used when absolutely necessary.

examples.title: Incomplete
examples.description: Use to indicate when a given task has not yet been completed. For example, when merchants haven’t fulfilled an order.

examples.title: Partially complete
examples.description: Use to indicate when a given task has been partially completed. For example, when merchants have partially fulfilled an order.

examples.title: Complete
examples.description: Use to indicate when a given task has been completed. For example, when merchants have fulfilled an order.

examples.title: With toneAndProgressLabelOverride
examples.description: Use when the tone and progress accessibilityLabels are not appropriate to a given context.

children.description: Informs merchants about important changes or persistent conditions. Use this component if you need to communicate to merchants in a prominent way. Banners are placed at the top of the page or section they apply to, and below the page or section header.
children.title: Banner
children.shortDescription: Informs merchants about important changes or persistent conditions in a prominent way.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to convey general information or actions that aren’t critical. For example, you might show a banner that asks for merchant feedback. Default banners contain lower priority information and should always be dismissible.

examples.title: Dismissible
examples.description: Make all banners dismissible, unless they contain critical information or an important action that merchants are required to take.

examples.title: With footer call-to-action
examples.description: Use when you want merchants to take an action after reading the banner.

examples.title: Informational
examples.description: Use to update merchants about a change or give them advice.

examples.title: Success
examples.description: Default to using toasts for success messages, unless the feedback is delayed, persistent, or has a call to action. Include next steps if applicable.

examples.title: Warning
examples.description: Use to display information that needs attention or that merchants need to take action on. Seeing these banners can be stressful for merchants so be cautious about using them.

examples.title: Critical
examples.description: Use to communicate problems that have to be resolved immediately for merchants to complete a task. For example, you will show this banner for orders with high fraud risk. Seeing these banners can be stressful for merchants so be cautious about using them.

examples.title: In a modal
examples.description: Banners inside of modals render with less spacing and a pared-back design to fit within a content context.

examples.title: With focus
examples.description: Banner can programmatically receive focus. Use this functionality to draw the merchant’s attention to the banner.

examples.title: In a card
examples.description: Banners inside of cards render with less spacing and a pared-back design to fit within a content context.

children.description: Use exception lists to help merchants notice important, standout information that adds extra context to a task. Exception lists often consist of a title and description. Each item in the list either has a bullet or icon at the front.
children.title: Exception list
children.shortDescription: Helps merchants notice important, standout information that adds extra context to a task.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use icons to add clarity or assist in visualizing the meaning

children.description: The loading component is used to indicate to merchants that a page is loading or an upload is processing.
children.title: Loading
children.shortDescription: Used to indicate to merchants that a page is loading or an upload is processing.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to indicate that the page is loading.

children.description: The progress bar component is used to visually represent the completion of a task or operation. It shows how much of the task has been completed and how much is still left.
children.title: Progress bar
children.shortDescription: Used to visually represent the completion of a task or operation.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use this component to visually represent the completion of a task or operation.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use the size option when you need to increase or decrease the visual weight of the progress bar.

examples.title: Colored
examples.description: Use the color option when you need to blend the progress bar in a context that calls for it, such as a progress toward success or where it’s the primary focus.

examples.title: Non-animated
examples.description: Use the animated prop when you want to show a static progress bar.

children.description: Skeleton body text is used to provide a low fidelity representation of content before it appears on the page, and improves load times perceived by merchants. Can be used for content in or outside of a card.
children.title: Skeleton body text
children.shortDescription: Provides a low fidelity representation of content before it appears, improving perceived load times.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use this component to represent a block of content being loaded. For example, you could use it to represent an entire product description card on the product page.

examples.title: Single line content
examples.description: Use this component to represent a short, single line of text, like a timestamp.

children.description: Skeleton display text is used to provide a low fidelity representation of content before it appears on the page, and improves load times perceived by merchants. Can be used for content in or outside of a card.
children.title: Skeleton display text
children.shortDescription: Provides a low fidelity representation of content before it appears, improving perceived load times.

examples.title: Medium and large
examples.description: Use this component to represent medium and large display text such as large metrics on the reports list page, or for page titles.

examples.title: Extra large
examples.description: Use this component to represent extra large display text.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use this component to represent small display text such as content headings.

children.description: Skeleton page is used with other skeleton loading components to provide a low fidelity representation of the user interface (UI) before content appears on the page. It improves load times perceived by merchants.
children.title: Skeleton page
children.shortDescription: Used with other skeleton loading components to provide a low fidelity representation of the UI before content appears.

examples.title: With dynamic content
examples.description: Use this component to compose a loading version of a page where the page title and header content are dynamic, meaning, the content changes.

examples.title: With static content
examples.description: Use this component to compose a loading version of a page where the page title and header content are known and stay the same.

children.description: Skeleton tabs are used to provide a low fidelity representation of content before it appears on the page, and improves load times perceived by merchants. Can be used for content in or outside of a card.
children.title: Skeleton tabs
children.shortDescription: Provides a low fidelity representation of content before it appears, improving perceived load times.

children.description: Skeleton thumbnail is used to provide a low fidelity representation of an image before it appears on the page, and improves load times perceived by merchants. Use for thumbnails in or outside of a card.
children.title: Skeleton thumbnail
children.shortDescription: Provides a low fidelity representation of an image before it appears, improving perceived load times.

examples.title: Medium
examples.description: Use this component to represent medium thumbnails.

examples.title: Large
examples.description: Use this component to represent large thumbnails.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use this component to represent small thumbnails.

examples.title: Extra small
examples.description: Use this component to represent extra small thumbnails.

children.description: Spinners are used to notify merchants that their action is being processed. For loading states, spinners should only be used for content that can’t be represented with skeleton loading components, like for data charts.
children.title: Spinner
children.shortDescription: Used to notify merchants that their action is being processed. Used for content that can’t be represented with skeleton loading components.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to notify merchants that their requested action is being processed.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Smaller than the default spinner.

examples.title: With focus management
examples.description: Use to direct the focus state from the control to the spinner, to the content.

children.description: The toast component is a non-disruptive message that appears at the bottom of the interface to provide quick, at-a-glance feedback on the outcome of an action.
children.title: Toast
children.shortDescription: A non-disruptive message that provides quick feedback on the outcome of an action.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to convey general confirmation or actions that aren’t critical. For example, you might show a toast message to inform the merchant that their recent action was successful.

examples.title: Multiple messages
examples.description: Use multiple toast messages to inform the merchant about distinct actions.

examples.title: With custom duration
examples.description: Use to shorten or lengthen the default duration of 5000 milliseconds.

examples.title: With action
examples.description: Use when a merchant has the ability to act on the message. For example, to undo a change or retry an action.

examples.title: Error
examples.description: Although error toast is still available and used in the system, we discourage its use. Reserve it for errors not caused by merchants, like a connection issue. Error toast should convey what went wrong in plain language and should not go over 3 words. For all other error message types, follow the [error message guidelines](https://polaris.shopify.com/patterns/error-messages).

posts.description: Establish hierarchy and communicate importance through text presentation.
posts.title: Typography

children.description: Typography helps establish hierarchy and communicate important content by creating clear visual patterns.
children.title: Text

examples.title: Heading
examples.description: Use to create various levels of hierarchy on the page.

examples.title: Body
examples.description: Use to create a range of body text. These styles are primarily used within components and blocks of text.

examples.title: Align
examples.description: Use to set text alignment.

examples.title: Weight
examples.description: Use to give text a range of font weights.

examples.title: Tone
examples.description: Use to set text tone (color).

examples.title: Inheritance
examples.description: Inherits props from a parent Text container

examples.title: Decoration
examples.description: Use to define text decoration

posts.description: Display, organize, and sort data for merchants to analyze and take action on.
posts.title: Tables

children.description: Data tables are used to organize and display all information from a data set. While a data visualization represents part of data set, a data table lets merchants view details from the entire set. This helps merchants compare and analyze the data.
children.title: Data table
children.shortDescription: Used to organize and display all information from a data set. Aimed to be as simple as possible for merchants.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to present small amounts of data for merchants to view statically.

examples.title: Sortable
examples.description: Use when clarity of the table’s content is needed. For example, to note the number of rows currently shown in a data table with pagination.

examples.title: With footer
examples.description: Use when clarity of the table’s content is needed. For example, to note the number of rows currently shown in a data table with pagination.

examples.title: With custom totals heading
examples.description: Use to provide a custom heading for the totals row.

examples.title: With totals in footer
examples.description: Use to reposition the totals row in a more appropriate location based on the data stored in the table for merchants to better understand its meaning.

examples.title: With row heading links
examples.description: Use to help merchants find relevant, finer grained data sets.

examples.title: With all of its elements
examples.description: Use as a broad example that includes most props available to data table.

examples.title: With fixed first columns
examples.description:
Use when the table contains many columns and it would benefit the merchant to see a set number of columns when scrolling to the right. For example, the first column in the "Sales by Product" report table is fixed because the product names are important to reference while analyzing the sales data in other columns.

When fixing multiple columns, ensure other data within the table is visible and not limited on smaller screens.

examples.title: With increased density and zebra striping
examples.description: Use as a broad example that includes most props available to data table.

examples.title: With sticky header enabled
examples.description: Use as a broad example that includes most props available to data table.

examples.title: With pagination
examples.description: Use when the table contains many rows and they need paginating.

children.description: An index table displays a collection of objects of the same type, like orders or products. The main job of an index table is to help merchants get an at-a-glance of the objects to perform actions or navigate to a full-page representation of it.
children.title: Index table

examples.title: Default
examples.description: An index table with simple items and no bulk actions, sorting, or filtering.

examples.title: With saved views, search, filtering, and sorting
examples.description: An index table with saved views, search, filtering, sorting, and bulk actions.

examples.title: With edit columns button
examples.description: An index table with edit columns, saved views, search, filtering, sorting, and bulk actions.

examples.title: With disabled rows
examples.description: An index table with saved views, search, filtering, sorting, and bulk actions.

examples.title: Small screen
examples.description: A small screen index table with simple items and no bulk actions, sorting, or filtering.

examples.title: Small screen with saved views, search, filtering, and sorting
examples.description: A small screen index table with saved views, search, filtering, sorting, and bulk actions.

examples.title: With empty state
examples.description: Use to explain the purpose of a index table when no resources exist yet. This allows a smooth transition from a list in a loading state to a list where zero, one, or many resources exist.

examples.title: With bulk actions
examples.description: Allows merchants to select items and perform an action on the selection.

examples.title: With multiple promoted bulk actions
examples.description: Allows merchants to select items and perform different actions on the selection.

examples.title: With bulk actions and selection across pages
examples.description: Allows merchants to select items, perform an action on the selection and select resources across pages.

examples.title: With loading state
examples.description: Notifies merchants that index table items are being processed.

examples.title: With filtering
examples.description: Allows merchants to narrow the index table to a subset of the original items.

examples.title: With sticky last column
examples.description: An index table with a sticky last column that stays visible on scroll. The last heading will also be sticky if not hidden.

examples.title: With row navigation link
examples.description: Use when clicking the row should navigate merchants to another page, like the row item's detail page. When a row contains a `Link` with the `dataPrimaryLink` prop set to `true`, clicking the row will trigger navigation to the link's `url` instead of selecting the row as well as trigger the callback set on the `IndexTable` `onNavigation` prop if provided.

examples.title: Without checkboxes
examples.description: An index table without checkboxes and bulk actions.

examples.title: With subheaders
examples.description: An index table with multiple table headers. Use to present merchants with resources grouped by a relevant data value to enable faster bulk selection.

examples.title: With pagination
examples.description: Use when the table contains many rows and they need paginating.

posts.description: Provide merchants with easy-to-use interfaces for selecting options, organizing information, and interacting with data.
posts.title: Lists

children.description: Action lists render a list of actions or selectable options. This component is usually placed inside a popover container to create a dropdown menu or to let merchants select from a list of options.
children.title: Action list

examples.title: In a popover
examples.description: Use for the least important actions so merchants aren’t distracted by secondary tasks. Can also be used for a set of actions that won’t fit in the available screen space.

examples.title: With icons or image
examples.description: Use when the items benefit from an associated action or image, such as a list of products.

examples.title: With an icon and a suffix
examples.description: Use when the items benefit from an associated action or image, such as a list of products.

examples.title: With sections
examples.description: Use when the items benefit from sections to help differentiate actions.

examples.title: With destructive item
examples.description: Use to visually indicate that an action list item is destructive.

examples.title: With help text
examples.description: Use help text when the normal Verb noun syntax for the actions does not provide sufficient context for the merchant.

examples.title: With a prefix and a suffix
examples.description: Use help text when the normal Verb noun syntax for the actions does not provide sufficient context for the merchant.

children.description: Description lists are a way to organize and explain related information. They’re particularly useful when you need to list and define terms such as in a glossary.
children.title: Description list
children.shortDescription: Used to present pairs of related information, like terms and definitions, or names and values, in a list format.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when you need to present merchants with a list of items or terms alongside descriptions and explanations.

children.description: Lists display a set of related text-only content. Each list item begins with a bullet or a number.
children.title: List

examples.title: Bulleted
examples.description: Use for a text-only list of related items that don’t need to be in a specific order and don’t require an icon or other indicator.

examples.title: Numbered
examples.description: Use for a text-only list of related items when an inherent order, priority, or sequence needs to be communicated.

examples.title: Extra Tight
examples.description: Use when there is limited space for a text-only list of related items when an inherent order, priority, or sequence needs to be communicated.

children.description: A Listbox is a vertical list of interactive options, with room for icons, descriptions, and other elements.
children.title: Listbox

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Basic implementation of a control element used to let merchants select options

examples.title: With Loading
examples.description: Implementation of a control element showing a loading indicator to let merchants know more options are being loaded

examples.title: With Action
examples.description: Implementation of a control element used to let merchants take an action

examples.title: With custom element
examples.description: Implementation of a control with custom rendering of options

examples.title: With search
examples.description: Use to help merchants browse, filter, and choose from a list of options.

children.description: The option list component lets you create a list of grouped items that merchants can pick from. This can include single selection or multiple selection of options. Option list usually appears in a popover, and sometimes in a modal or a sidebar. Option lists are styled differently than choice lists and should not be used within a form, but as a standalone menu.
children.title: Option list

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use for a group of similar selectable items when only one should be selectable at once.

examples.title: Multiple
examples.description: Use when you have a group of similar selectable items and more than one item can be selected at once.

examples.title: With sections
examples.description: Use sections when you have multiple groups of similar selectable items.

examples.title: In a popover
examples.description: Use when a set of selections won’t fit in the available screen space.

children.description: Resource items represent specific objects within a collection, such as products or orders. They provide contextual information on the resource type and link to the object’s detail page.
children.title: Resource item

examples.title: Default
examples.description: A basic resource item with its details filled in at the point of use.

examples.title: With media
examples.description: The media element can hold an [avatar](https://polaris.shopify.com/components/avatar), [thumbnail](https://polaris.shopify.com/components/thumbnail), or other small-format graphic.

examples.title: With shortcut actions
examples.description: Shortcut actions present popular actions from the resource’s details page for easy access. A shortcut action should be available on every item in the list.

examples.title: With vertical alignment
examples.description: Use to adjust the vertical alignment of item content.

children.description: A resource list displays a collection of objects of the same type, like products or customers. The main job of a resource list is to help merchants find an object and navigate to a full-page representation of it.
children.title: Resource list

examples.title: Default
examples.description: A resource list with simple items and no bulk actions, sorting, or filtering.

examples.title: With empty state
examples.description: Use to explain the purpose of a list of resources when no resources exist yet. This allows a smooth transition from a list in a loading state to a list where zero, one, or many resources exist.

examples.title: With selection and no bulk actions
examples.description: A resource list with simple items and selection.

examples.title: With bulk actions
examples.description: Allows merchants to select items and perform an action on the selection.

examples.title: With loading state
examples.description: Notifies merchants that list items are being processed.

examples.title: With total count
examples.description: Use to indicate that the number of resources shown is a subset of the total number of resources in the list.

examples.title: With sorting
examples.description: Allows merchants to change the way the list is sorted by selecting one of several options from a [Select](https://polaris.shopify.com/components/select) control.

examples.title: With alternate tool
examples.description: Allows merchants to add an alternate tool in the current sort option location when sort may not be the most relevant action for the current list.

examples.title: With filtering
examples.description: Allows merchants to narrow the resource list to a subset of the original items.

examples.title: With a custom empty search result state
examples.description: Allows merchants to narrow the resource list to a subset of the original items. If the filters or search applied return no results, then display a custom empty search state.

examples.title: With item shortcut actions
examples.description: Shortcut actions are intended to provide quick access to popular actions from the resource’s details page. They are shown when the mouse is hovered over the list item, and are not shown on small screen devices, so the action must also be accessible in another way.

examples.title: With persistent item shortcut actions
examples.description: Use persistent shortcut actions in rare cases when the action cannot be made available on the item’s details page. Persistent shortcut actions roll up into an overflow menu on small screens.

examples.title: With multiselect
examples.description: Allows merchants to select or deselect multiple items at once.

examples.title: With all of its elements
examples.description: Use as a broad example that includes most props available to resource list.

examples.title: With pagination
examples.description: Use when the list contains many rows and they need paginating.

posts.description: Access resources and move between sections, pages, or views in a structured and intuitive way.
posts.title: Navigation

children.description: Footer help is used to refer merchants to more information related to the product or feature they’re using.
children.title: Footer help

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to direct merchants to more information related to the product or feature they’re working on.

children.description: The Fullscreen bar is a header component that should be presented at the top of an app when it is in fullscreen mode. This is designed to ensure a uniform placement for a button to exit that mode. The Fullscreen bar can be customized by adding children.
children.title: Fullscreen bar

examples.title: With children
examples.description: Use to provide structure for the top of an application while in fullscreen mode.

examples.title: No children
examples.description: Use this default to show ONLY the Back button.

children.description: Links take users to another place, and usually appear within or directly following a sentence.
children.title: Link

examples.title: Default links
examples.description: Use for text links inside a paragraph or for standalone text. Default links open in the same browser tab.

examples.title: Monochrome
examples.description: Use for text links that are the same color as the surrounding text.

examples.title: Monochrome in a banner
examples.description: Monochrome styles will be applied to links rendered within a `Banner`.

examples.title: External link
examples.description: Use for text links that should open in a new browser tab (or window, depending on the merchant’s browser settings). Use this only when a default link might disrupt the merchant’s workflow.

children.description: The navigation component is used to display the primary navigation in the sidebar of the frame of an application. Navigation includes a list of links that merchants use to move between sections of the application.
children.title: Navigation

examples.title: Default

examples.title: With multiple secondary navigations

children.description: Use pagination to let merchants move through an ordered collection of items that has been split into pages. On the web, pagination uses buttons to move back and forth between pages. On iOS and Android, pagination uses infinite scrolling.
children.title: Pagination

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use for pagination of resources.

examples.title: With keyboard navigation
examples.description: Attach standard keyboard shortcuts to important pagination controls.

examples.title: With label
examples.description: Add a label between navigation buttons to provide more context of the content being viewed by the user.

examples.title: With table type
examples.description: Use for pagination at the bottom of tables or lists.

children.description: Use to alternate among related views within the same context.
children.title: Tabs
children.shortDescription: Used to alternate among related views within the same context.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use for most cases, especially when the number of tabs may be more than three.

examples.title: Inside of a Card
examples.description: Use to display tabs inside of a [Card](/components/layout-and-structure/card).

examples.title: Fitted
examples.description: Use when tabs contain a few (2 or 3) items within a narrow column.

examples.title: With actions
examples.description: Use when actions need to be performed on a tab.

examples.title: With badge content
examples.description: Use to inform a piece of information about the tabs.

examples.title: With custom disclosure
