children.description: The top bar is a header component that allows merchants to search, access menus, and navigate by clicking on the logo. It’s always visible at the top of interfaces like Shopify or Shopify Plus. Third-party apps that use the top bar can customize the color to match their brand using the app provider component and are required to use their own logo.
children.title: Top bar
children.shortDescription: Appears at the top of the page and is used to brand and navigate major applications areas.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to provide structure for the top of an application. Style the top bar component using the app provider component with a theme. Providing just the `background` key for the top bar component theme will result in intelligent defaults being set for complementary colors with contrasting text.

posts.description: Display contextual elements on top of the main admin interface that provide additional information or functionality.
posts.title: Overlays

children.description: Modals are overlays that require merchants to take an action before they can continue interacting with the rest of Shopify. They can be disruptive and should be used thoughtfully and sparingly.
children.title: Modal
children.shortDescription: Used to interrupt merchants with urgent information, details, or actions.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use as the default option for a modal.

examples.title: With primary action
examples.description: Use to let merchants take a key action.

examples.title: With destructive primary action
examples.description: Use to let merchants take a key action that cannot be undone.

examples.title: With primary and secondary actions
examples.description: Use to let merchants take key actions at the bottom of the modal.

examples.title: Large
examples.description: Use when you need to increase the width of your modal.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use when you need to decrease the width of your modal.

examples.title: Without a title
examples.description: A title is required for accessibility, but you may hide it.

examples.title: With scroll listener
examples.description: Use to implement infinite scroll of modal content.

examples.title: With activator ref
examples.description: Provide an activator ref when it’s more convenient than providing an element. This ensures proper focus management when closing the modal. See the [accessibility features of a modal](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices/examples/dialog-modal/dialog.html) for more information regarding focus.

examples.title: Without an activator prop
examples.description: Use an external activator when technical limitations prevent you from passing the activator as an element or a ref. Make sure to focus the activator on close when choosing this approach. See the [accessibility features of a modal](https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-practices/examples/dialog-modal/dialog.html) for more information regarding focus.

children.description: Popovers are small overlays that open on demand. They let merchants access additional content and actions without cluttering the page.
children.title: Popover
children.shortDescription: Small overlays that open on demand and close when the merchant interacts with any other part of Shopify. Used to surface secondary information or actions.

examples.title: With action list
examples.description: Use when presenting a set of actions in a disclosable menu.

examples.title: With content and actions
examples.description: Use to present a combination of content, instructions, and actions in a panel for tasks that are of low or secondary importance to the current page. When used this way, popovers provide useful entry points to related features without overwhelming merchants.

examples.title: With form components
examples.description: Use to present secondary input tasks on demand.

examples.title: With lazy loaded list
examples.description: Use to present merchants with a list that dynamically loads more items on scroll or arrow down.

examples.title: With searchable listbox
examples.description: Use to help merchants browse, filter, and choose from a list of options.

children.description: Tooltips are floating labels that briefly explain the function of a user interface element. They can be triggered when merchants hover, focus, tap, or click.
children.title: Tooltip

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use only when necessary to provide an explanation for an interface element.

examples.title: Visible only with child interaction
examples.description: Use when the tooltip overlays interactive elements when active, for example a form input. The `dismissOnMouseOut` prop prevents the tooltip from remaining active when mouse hover or focus leaves its `children` and enters the tooltip's content.

examples.title: With persistence on click
examples.description: Use to present a tooltip that remains open if activated by click or keypress.

examples.title: With suffix
examples.description: Use when merchants benefit from information supplemental to the tooltip content. For example, to present a keyboard shortcut beside the content of a tooltip that describes an icon button.

posts.description: Utilities are core tools for managing the structure of the admin and global settings.
posts.title: Utilities

children.description: App provider is a required component that enables sharing global settings throughout the hierarchy of your application.
children.title: App provider

examples.title: Default
examples.description: AppProvider works by default without any additional options passed to it.

examples.title: With i18n
examples.description: With an `i18n`, `AppProvider` will provide these translations to polaris components. See [using translations](https://polaris.shopify.com/components/app-provider#using-translations)

examples.title: With linkComponent
examples.description: With a `linkComponent`, the app provider component will override the links used in other components. For example you may want to use the `Link` component provided by `react-router` throughout your application instead of the default `a` tag.

children.description: The collapsible component is used to put long sections of information under a block that merchants can expand or collapse.
children.title: Collapsible
children.shortDescription: Hides content and allows merchants to expand it. Used to hide optional settings, information, and actions.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use for a basic “show more” interaction when you need to display more content.

children.description: The frame component, while not visible in the user interface itself, provides the structure for an application. It wraps the main elements and houses the primary navigation, top bar, toast, and contextual save bar components.
children.title: Frame
children.shortDescription: Creates the structure of the Shopify admin. All of the main sections of the admin are nested in the frame.

examples.title: In an application
examples.description: Use to present the frame structure and all of its elements.

examples.title: With an offset
examples.description: Use to present the frame structure and all of its elements with an offset provided to the theme.

children.description: The scrollable component is a container for long form content, such as terms of service, that allows for scrolling so merchants can expose more text as they read.
children.title: Scrollable
children.shortDescription: Used in components with too much content for the available vertical space. Embeds long-form content in components like modals and popovers.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when you need to make a region within the page independently scrollable. It’s often used in modals and other panes where it’s helpful to provide an extra visual cue that content exists below or above the fold.

examples.title: To child component
examples.description: Use when you need to programmatically scroll a child component into view in the scrollable container.

posts.description: Deprecated components will be removed in future major versions of Polaris. These components could be deprecated for a number of reasons and should be avoided. These components will show warnings in the component file and provide details for alternative usage. For more information, check out the component lifecycles.
posts.title: Deprecated
posts.shortDescription: Deprecated components will be removed in future major versions of Polaris. They should be avoided and will show warnings.

children.description: Caption text size is smaller than the recommended size for general reading. On web, it should be used only in a graph or as a timestamp for a list item. On Android and iOS, it can also be used as help text or as other kinds of secondary text for list items.
children.title: Caption
children.shortDescription: Caption text is smaller than the recommended size for general reading. Used in graphs, timestamps, or as secondary text.

children.description: Display styles make a bold visual statement. Use them to create impact when the main goal is visual storytelling. For example, use display text to convince or reassure merchants such as in marketing content or to capture attention during onboarding.
children.title: Display text
children.shortDescription: Display styles make a bold visual statement. Used for visual storytelling, marketing content, or capturing attention.

children.description: Headings are used as the titles of each major section of a page in the interface. For example, card components generally use headings as their title.
children.title: Heading
children.shortDescription: Used as the titles of each major section of a page in the interface, like in card components.

children.description: This is the legacy version of the Card component which is in the process of being updated to a more flexible and composable API. Cards are used to group similar concepts and tasks together to make Shopify easier for merchants to scan, read, and get things done.
children.title: Legacy card
children.shortDescription: Legacy version of the Card component. Used to group similar concepts and tasks together for easier scanning and reading.
keywords: card with call to action in the footer
card with call to action in the heading
card with call to action in a section
card with button in the footer
card with button in the heading

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when you have a simple message to communicate to merchants that doesn’t require any secondary steps.

examples.title: With header actions
examples.description: Use for less important card actions, or actions merchants may do before reviewing the contents of the card. For example, merchants may want to add items to a card containing a long list, or enter a customer’s new address.

examples.title: With footer actions
examples.description: Use footer actions for a card’s most important actions, or actions merchants should do after reviewing the contents of the card. For example, merchants should review the contents of a shipment before an important action like adding tracking information. Footer actions can be left or right aligned with the `footerActionAlignment` prop.

examples.title: With multiple footer actions
examples.description: When multiple secondary footer actions are provided, they will render in an action list popover activated by a disclosure button. The disclosure button text can be customized with the `secondaryFooterActionsDisclosureText` prop.

examples.title: With custom footer actions
examples.description: Use to present actionable content that is optional or not the primary purpose of the page.

examples.title: With destructive footer action
examples.description: Use when a card action will delete merchant data or be otherwise difficult to recover from.

examples.title: With multiple sections
examples.description: Use when you have two related but distinct pieces of information to communicate to merchants. Multiple sections can help break up complicated concepts to make them easier to scan and understand.

examples.title: With multiple titled sections
examples.description: Use when you have two related but distinct pieces of information to communicate to merchants that are complex enough to require a title to introduce them.

examples.title: With sections and actions
examples.description: Use when your card section has actions that apply only to that section.

examples.title: With subsection
examples.description: Use when your card sections need further categorization.

examples.title: With destructive action
examples.description: Use when a card action applies only to one section and will delete merchant data or be otherwise difficult to recover from.

examples.title: With a subdued section
examples.description: Use to indicate when one of the sections in your card contains inactive or disabled content.

examples.title: With subdued for secondary content
examples.description: Use for content that you want to deprioritize. Subdued cards don’t stand out as much as cards with white backgrounds so don’t use them for information or actions that are critical to merchants.

examples.title: With separate header
examples.description: Use to be able to use custom React elements as header content.

examples.title: With custom React Node title
examples.description: Use to render custom content such as icons, links, or buttons in a card section’s header.

examples.title: With all elements
examples.description: Use as a broad example that includes most props available to card.

examples.title: With flushed sections
examples.description: Use when you need further control over the spacing of your card sections.

children.description: This is a legacy version of the Filters component, which is a composite component that filters the items of a list or table.
children.title: Legacy filters
children.shortDescription: Legacy version of the Filters component. Used to filter the items of a list or table.

children.description: This is the legacy version of the Stack component which is in the process of being updated to a more flexible and composable API. Use to lay out a horizontal row of components or to achieve no-fuss vertical centering. A stack is made of flexible items that wrap each of the stack’s children. Options provide control of the wrapping, spacing, and relative size of the items in the stack.
children.title: Legacy stack
children.shortDescription: Legacy version of the Stack component. Used for layout of a horizontal row of components or vertical centering.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to quickly lay out a horizontal row of components and maintain their relative sizes. On small screens, children rows wrap down to additional rows as needed.

examples.title: Non-wrapping
examples.description: Use to create a stack where the children will not wrap to new rows on small screens. As noted above, the wrap option defaults to true. This means you must explicitly set it to false to turn it off.

examples.title: Spacing
examples.description: Use to control spacing of items in a stack in standard increments. Use tight for less spacing, loose for more spacing, or none to remove normal spacing altogether.

examples.title: Vertical centering
examples.description: Use to vertically center a set of items that have different heights.

examples.title: Fill available space proportionally
examples.description: Use to have the stack’s items fill the horizontal space in the container but maintain their relative proportions.

examples.title: Where items fill space evenly
examples.description: Use to have the stack’s items fill the horizontal space in the container and be equal widths, regardless of their content.

examples.title: Where a single item fills the remaining space
examples.description: Use for aligning buttons or secondary content to the right edge of another element, allowing it to wrap below on small screens.

children.description: Use to give merchants control over a feature or option that can be turned on or off.
children.title: Setting toggle
children.shortDescription: Used to control a feature or option that can be turned on or off.

examples.title: With primitive components
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to toggle a setting that has an on or off state. Display the name of the setting and provide a description so merchants have the context needed to decide whether or not to enable the setting. This pattern is built using the layout and typography components, instead of the deprecated `SettingToggle` component.

examples.title: With deprecated component
examples.description: The setting toggle component is deprecated. The "With primitive components" example is the recommended way to build the setting toggle pattern.

children.description: A sheet is a large container that enters from the edge of the screen when triggered by the merchant. It’s used to provide merchants with actions and information contextual to the page. It doesn’t interrupt their flow like a modal.
children.title: Sheet
children.shortDescription: A large container providing actions and information contextual to the page without interrupting flow like a modal.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use as the default option for a sheet.

examples.title: With searchable listbox
examples.description: Use to help merchants browse, filter, and choose from a list of options.

children.description: Subheadings are used for the title of any sub-sections in top-level page sections.
children.title: Subheading
children.shortDescription: Used for the title of any sub-sections in top-level page sections.

children.description: A text container is used to wrap text elements such as paragraphs, headings, and lists to give them vertical spacing.
children.title: Text container
children.shortDescription: Used to wrap text elements like paragraphs, headings, and lists for vertical spacing.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use this component for default vertical spacing.

examples.title: Tight
examples.description: Use the tight spacing option to relate content topics to each other.

examples.title: Loose
examples.description: Use the loose spacing option to separate concepts that are independent of each other.

children.description: Text style enhances text with additional visual meaning. For example, using subdued text to de-emphasize it from its surrounding text.
children.title: Text style
children.shortDescription: Enhances text with additional visual meaning, like using subdued text to de-emphasize it.

children.description: Use when an element needs to be available to assistive technology (for example, a screen reader) but otherwise hidden.
